Department of Agriculture and Technical Instruction for Ireland.
FOOD PRODUCTION SCHEMES. IRELAND.
Memorandum prepared in compliance with Chief Secretary's Minute of 17th March, 1917.
Week ended 17th October, 1917.
The following is a brief statement on the work of the Department during the past week in furtherance of increased Food Production ? Ireland, including action taken in connection with the organisation of supplies of requisites for tillage and harvest operations in 1918:-
LOANS FOR AGRICULTURAL IMPLEMENTS.
Forty-eight applications for loans for agricultural implemengs were received by the Department during the past week. The total value of machinery ordered to date under tho Scheme amounts to Â£109,910.
TILLAGE DEFAULTERS.
A considerable number of occcupiers who are in default in respect of the cultivation of their holdings under the Defence of the Realm Regulative have now given undertakings to plough up before the end of the year the areas in respect of which they are in default.
HARVESTING OPERATIONS.
All the corn is now cut except a few isolated fields in late northern districts. The heavy rain of the past week has further delated the completion of stacking and thatching these crops. The returns made by the Agricultural instructors in the different counties ?now that much loss damage than was anticipated has be on done to the coin by the in-element weatner ? prevailed during the harvest season.
Owing to the water-logged condition of the soil, the digging of the ?ctato crop has been delayed, and some reports received show that thu? tubers are commencing to rot on heavy or retentive soils, Unsprayed crops are reported in be badly affected with disease, and to show a striking reduction in the yield of marketable potatoes as compared with ?rops that were properly sprayed.
Late out meadown have been practically lost owing largely to the delayed harvest and the rain.
DRAINAGE OF AGRICULTURAL LAND.
During the past week the issue of notices requiring the cleansing of ?teroourses, which had been suspended during the harvest., was resumed and notices have now been issued in respect of sixty-five complaints, of those who have received notices have stated that it will be impossible to clean their watercourses, as they are flooded at present, whilst others, for the same reason, have asked for an extension of the ? within which the work should be done.

FLAX SEED (IRELAND) ORDER. 1917.
Twenty-two further cases of failure to comply with the Flax Seed (Ireland) Order have been reported.
Proceedings will be duly taken against the defaulters.
Nine flax apprentices have concluded their training and arrangements are being made to place them in districts where their services as instructors will be most needed.
The question of obtaining the large amount of seed which will be required from abroad for Sowing in 1913 and ensuing years continues to engage the Department's careful attention. The Department understand that a now Administrative Committee to deal with the matter has been set up in London, and they are awaiting information as to the spots which the Committee propose should be taken to secure the end in view.
TRANSIT OF FARMING REQUISITES.
During the week representations were received regarding facilities for the conveyance of agricultural machinery and requirements from stations in England to Irish stations. The necessary action was taken in each case.
MAINTENANCE OF LIVE STOCK.
During the period from 9th to 15th October, inclusive, 1973 applications for licences to slaughter or export under the Order relating to bredeenig some were received and 74 licences were issued. During the same period 53 applications for licences to export horses under the Horses (Prohibition of Exportation from Ireland Order) were received and 45 licences were issued. One licence was granted under the Order relating to in-calf cattle.
